How do we know what Earth's climate was like long ago? If you look closely, there are clues just about everywhere across our globe. Some are easy to see and others are more subtle. 
@NASAClimate
 scientist Dr. Gavin Schmidt explains.

"'NASA for all.' That's something that I think is really important because we are the universe, right? We are made of star stuff."

Celebrate #Pride and learn how Rebecca Sirmons helps tell the story of the universe as NASA TV's executive producer: http://go.nasa.gov/3IVxzj7

#MissionToPsyche is on track for launch in October 2023!

An independent review board found JPL’s response to address factors contributing to the mission’s 2022 launch delay has been "world class."

LIVE: Tune in as we review next steps for the Psyche mission, set to launch no earlier than Oct. 2023. The spacecraft will study a metal-rich asteroid of the same name that may be the partial core of a building block of rocky planets in our solar system.

You're looking at 45,000+ galaxies.

This image was taken as part of the JWST Advanced Deep Extragalactic Survey (JADES) — a massive science program that’s revolutionizing what we know about galaxies in the early universe: https://go.nasa.gov/3CdLq0s

Here are the highlights

Hurricane season in the Atlantic begins today. Our unique perspective from space allows us to study storms and their evolution, providing data to support forecasting and disaster responses: https://go.nasa.gov/3fYNZYE

Hot new bombshells enter the villa.

Otherwise invisible to the unaided eye, infrared data from 
@NASAWebb
 and x-ray data from 
@ChandraXray
 make details in these proper fit cosmic wonders available by mapping the data to colors that humans can perceive:
https://go.nasa.gov/43wTsx9

Victor Glover: captain, pilot, astronaut.

Glover most recently served as the pilot of the NASA 
@SpaceX
 #Crew1 mission and will be one of four astronauts flying aboard the #Artemis II mission around the Moon. https://go.nasa.gov/31cfXJh

Celebrate #MilitaryAppreciationMonth.

Hey, you: Get a load of this cloud! High-altitude ice clouds (like this one) can help regulate Earth's temperature by reflecting energy from the Sun.

A new 
@NASAEarth
 mission called PoISIR aims to study them in greater detail to improve climate forecasts. https://go.nasa.gov/3IAfgjj
